Video Title: IGTA - Cost Cutting  - Sports & Entertainment Immigration Strategies
Video Folder Link: IGTA - Cost Cutting  - Sports & Entertainment Immigration Strategies
Recording File: IGTA - Cost Cutting  - Sports & Entertainment Immigration Strategies.mp4
Audio File: IGTA - Cost Cutting  - Sports & Entertainment Immigration Strategies.mp3
Txt Wrap: There is a reason why the agent-based structure is so important in the sports and entertainment industry. One is that a lot of these are on short notice opportunities and there is simply no time to wait months long for the H-1B process where you have to... advertise a job placement, place the candidate, wait for the season to be open to apply and just sit there and wait, and then do consular processing. You don't have time for that in sports. A lot of that is very short notice. The other part is cost. In sports and entertainment, you know, you think about a movie, there are sometimes hundreds of people that have a small part in making the movie happen. And if you're paying for O1 visas or even H1 visas for that, the cost on that would be astronomical. And that's a lot of reasons why. agent-based petition is so prevalent when it comes to this. But you have the opportunity to benefit from that too. We know that employers are not only filing new H-1Bs, of which only about 18% of the half a million that are applied for every year get through, but there's also significant costs with renewing the visas and also with employee transfers. We know that premium processing right now is costing around almost $4,000 with USCIS and filing fees. And that doesn't even get to the probably 4,000 or so that you'll spend with your immigration council if you're not doing the H-1B process in-house. What we do is make it so that you're pretty much paying the same that you would for a retained recruiter on one job posting to establish the relationship and contract we need to make our US agent structure work for you. And if you're thinking about you're just paying that once as opposed to some companies are paying for H-1B visas hundreds or even a thousand times over per year, it's a significant cost reduction then it's a significant reduction on stress of the personnel because the other thing that we do is make it so that the talent that's placed with you through us will come back to us in our own immigration council to ask questions and we train our talent to refrain from asking that from the employer Even when it comes to such thing as permanent residence, in our case, the O-1 visa is an excellent pathway to the EB-1A visa that does not need a employer at all. It's a self-petition visa. And then we also kind of tend to deal in industries where we can do national interest waiver for EB-2, which is another way that we can get our talent green cards that they want to do without having to involve the employer.

We know that most employers that deal with foreign nationals are serving as the direct employer, meaning I've hired this employee and I'm also filing the visa for them in a direct employment situation where we specify, we probably even advertise exactly what the beneficiary will be doing. The only difference here with what we do is that the employer does not have to serve as the petitioner and gets to stay out of the process when it comes to the whole visa. Now, we get a lot of questions about how does this work on our compliance side as far as having I-9 compliance and how to categorize the worker. Do we have to do them as a 1099 or can we have them on W-2? The great thing about the O-1 visa is it can be either one. But what we do to make sure that the I-9 compliance stays in place, just the same as if you were filing your own H-1B, is set up the U.S. agent for multiple employers scenario so that USCIS knows that the employer is actually a third party and then that employer can do their normal compliance issues and, you know, dotting Is and crossing Ts to make them comfortable with how the employee is categorized and how the employee has obtained their work authorization. So there's no issues with USCIS, and there are also no issues with how you have to report your employees versus contractor status to your shareholders and stakeholders.

And that's enough to support the EV-A when it's captured properly in the arguments. Now, when doing the EB-A, you have to look at it structurally to see your timeline and where you need to be in the world. For example, if you're in the United States, you have the option of filing for your EB-A first and then seeing if you get approved and then file for your adjustment of status. And that's advantageous to maybe if you have a borderline application. But in this case, if this person's in the United States, it's probably best for them to file for EB-A and their adjustment of status for green card at the same time. When you do it that way, you will have to stay in the United States for probably six to eight months while you wait for your adjustment. Well, you wait for your parole, advanced parole, which allows you to travel in and out of the United States while you're waiting. And for your work authorization, it gives you a blanket authorization to work anywhere that you want to, but it also takes about six to eight months. So when you're doing EB-A with the adjustment status, be sure that you can stay in place for a while. Now, if you're outside of the United States or you need to be back and forth, then you need to look at consular processing. That's when you'll do your EB-A, get it approved, and then apply for consular processing for your green card. at a consulate abroad, which usually should be your country of origin if the embassy is open. If it's not, then there'll be alternatives that you can go to and go to third countries, third party countries to do that in the circumstance that the embassy is not available in your country at the time. But in this case, fencing, great sport. This person has a bronze medal in the World Cup, a first olympian from their countries and the youth olympic games two bronze asian championships and a silver medal in the asian championships this is a excellent candidate I'd say you can go straight for the ev-one a and then just make the decision whether you want to stay in the united states if you're already here and adjust status or if you want to wait and get consular processing If it's the case that you're in a hurry and you're abroad, it might not make sense to apply for the EB-A, but instead apply for the O-A, which this person is also qualified for. One is that the eligibility criteria for O-1s tend to be pretty subjective as opposed to objective, and there's room for interpretation. And that comes to the second part. This interpretation is done by people. And sometimes it's just the case that somebody is a jerk or they are untrained over at USCIS. But when you do O-1 visas, you're going to run into some inconsistency. The question comes in what to do from there. And the particular inquiry that we're getting is somebody that's come to us after dealing with another attorney. So we have to put that into the play. We at our law firm, and the law firms we're affiliated with, primarily only do O1s, P1s, and extraordinary ability visas. So usually on the presentation of the visa is top notch. It's the best foot forward that we can put together for client, keeping in mind the context that we get from hundreds and hundreds of 01s petitions. For other attorneys, they might just do a couple visas per year or every other year. And so they wouldn't be privy to the type of feedback you get from practicing a lot in this area. So that's one thing. Maybe there was a problem with the preparation of your petition and it wasn't as thorough towards being a great petition as it could be. The second part is maybe you got an officer that was not good or maybe you got an officer that's not trained. Nonetheless, when this happens, the advice that I would probably give is usually the same as that. Appeals are not all that helpful and they take a long time. Appeals go right back to the board of immigration, depending Now you do it, usually that's the case. And one, they take a long time. They usually don't get back until six or eight months or maybe even longer. And they cost around the same as a regular processing filing fee. So what we tell for O-1 visa people that have unfortunately been denied is usually just go ahead and file another petition just because you'll get probably another fresh set of eyes. The timing will be the same. It's supposed to be reviewed on its own merits. And it's an opportunity to bolster your arguments or even go with a new counsel that can be maybe more helpful for you and present your eligibility arguments in a better way that USCIS will find persuasive. So that's what I usually say in most denials is to either file another file or even just litigate because I don't find that appeals are all that successful because you're going right back to the same entity that denied to be in the first place and they stand 10. to stick with the decision-making made by other people in their office, which makes sense. But I hope this is helpful to you out there, and hopefully you're avoiding denials. But if you do, choose the most sensical way forward.

And the way that we do that is we say you're a world-class cheerleading professional. We don't say a world-class cheerleader or world-class cheerleading coach. The other thing that's helpful, of course, is the success of your pupils under the comparative evidence theory. You can use the accomplishments and the memberships. Video Title: IGTA - Rollin Training - Universities - What kind of visas do we do

Txt Wrap: all right welcome to what we do with universities module two and this one is about what type of visa categories do we deal with and that is a great question so In general, speaking of what we deal with and what we don't deal with, there's only two categories of visas that we are talking about. One is the H-1B visa. H-1B visa is the most common work visa in the United States, and that's usually what employers are looking to do for like Accenture when they get all of the tech people. That's the main one that universities use to get faculty. And there's nothing really special about it, but there's a lot of limitations. 1 is, you can only work with that particular employer for new ones. There's a capture how many of them can be given out. And then a lot of times they don't have the flexibility, or it's not the right time of year to apply for those. And it's common that employers, there's just not enough visas out there to get them. The, because there's a cap. Sometimes there's a time of the year. You can't file for new H1Bs all year round. There's a certain time of year where you can apply for them if they've never had one before. The third limitation is for the person that's under H1B themselves, they might be uncomfortable with only having that with that employer. Like they can't go start their own business with it, and they can't go immediately work for another employer with an H1B. And they can't work for multiple employers with just one H-1B. So that's the thing that we're usually trying to solve is how to get foreign nationals without an H-1B being involved. And that's where we do is O-1A visas. O-1As are for extraordinary ability for nationals. But it usually means that they've risen to the top of their field. There's a couple of advantages that come with this. One is there's no cap on these visas, so we don't have to worry about how many have been issued. There's also a lot of work flexibility that you can work with multiple employers on that same O-1 visa and start your own business without having to change them. And the O-1 visas also come with the ability to get O-3 visas for family members. So if you have children under 21 and spouses, they can get O-3 visas for the three years that you can get the O-1. The other thing that's great about an O-1 is that it's a great segue into an EB-1A green card. It's a green card where you don't need an employer at all. You can self-sponsor yourself. And the way that you get one is similar arguments to the O-1. The reason why a lot of employers don't do 01s is because they are very nuanced and hard to make those arguments to show that someone's one of the top in the world at their field. And they tend to be much more expensive to do than 01A on legal fees. Yeah, 01s usually cost maybe like three times as more on legal fees as H-1B. And that's for that reason that we're pretty selective about who we put in this program because it costs us two time and money to file the applications to do O1. So we want to make sure that we think there are great candidates for it. Now, I did mention on the student side that we do have an opportunity to work with H1Bs, but it's with a partner, another business. So there's no cap and no limitation on the time of year that certain nonprofits can file for H1Bs. So one of the things we can do is reverse a student to that business so that they can kind of be parked here and not have to leave if they have no other alternatives. So that's why I brought that up. So we do, if they do not fit into O1, we can refer them, students, graduating students to our partner nonprofit that can hold them there. And it costs like $4,000 a month. They give them like 15 hours of work stuff to do, and they pay them from that 4,000 and figure things out. But that's just what it costs. You have a question? No.

Txt Wrap: Hello, thank you for paying attention to this talk about Innovative Global Talent Agency and how we partner with universities to offer several solutions that help with the international side when it comes to both faculty and both to graduating students. First, let's talk about faculty. We know that universities are some of the premier organizations that apply for H-1B visas, which are the traditional way that foreign nationals that have masters come and work at universities. But we also know that these visas have their limitations, especially when it comes to faculty that doesn't want to be full time and maybe when it's in between when you can file for H-1B visas. The solution that we bring is we have a subscription to where we can do O1 visas for top tier faculty members to where the university will pay us a monthly subscription fee. And for there, that will allow them to have access to our talent pool that does include professor worthy minds from all over the world in some of the hard to find industries. and they can also suggest people to us that are interested in the university or they're interested in as part of the recruitment process to bring them in where we'll handle the o1 visa and make the person available for working uh with the university and it would be pretty immediate they wouldn't have to wait for the visa as if they're applying themselves we would go ahead and take care of that for them so we have talent that they might want and they can also suggest talent to us where they don't want to deal with the h-1b process The next thing we do is we help students. We help them, students that are graduating, stay in the country with proper work authorization, especially if they don't have a job or if they want to be entrepreneurs or if they are athletes or something similar. For athletes, we can serve as petitioner, which means we sign off on their visa work, and then they're able to use the P or O-1 visa to do competitions. This is common with track. And then if they are doing something like tennis, where they might be coaching, if they are eligible, we can apply for O-1 visas on their behalf and actively try to place them with clubs and sponsorships. On the other side, for the more higher skilled graduates at the master's and especially the PhD level, we can do a couple of things. One is We have a relationship with a nonprofit that helps people that are in the H-1B category be able to stay in the country under that category by putting them in this nonprofit program where they work probably about 10 hours a week and they can self-fund themselves, which I'll get into the technical side of that. But that's one thing that we offer for the master's level and the bachelor level candidates is the opportunity to participate in the fellowship program to basically stay under H-1B status until they get picked up by an employer, which may be on their own volition or through us if we're actively trying to place them. The other thing we can do is the same thing we do with faculty, is where we'll serve as petitioner for O1 visas for people that are usually at the higher master's degree, LLM, or PhD programs. And we will serve as their sponsor and then also find a place to put jobs with our employer partners that are similar to what we do with the universities, where they will pay us a fee. and subscription, which allows us to place the O-1 visa holders with them for placement. And those are the services we can offer to the university levels. One is for faculty. The university can subscribe to us as an employer client, which allows us to do the O-1 visa as a US agent for multiple employers. Second is we can help graduating students that do not have jobs be able to get H-1Bs with a nonprofit that they can self-fund. Third is we can offer the O-1 solution for the higher tier graduates at the PhD, LLM, and STEM master's programs. Thank you very much.

Video Title: Sherrod Seward Speaks on Self Petitioning as Entrepreneur under O-1A visa
Video Folder Link: Sherrod Seward Speaks on Self Petitioning as Entrepreneur under O-1A visa
Recording File: Sherrod Seward Speaks on Self Petitioning as Entrepreneur under O-1A visa.mp4
Audio File: Sherrod Seward Speaks on Self Petitioning as Entrepreneur under O-1A visa.mp3
Txt Wrap: For entrepreneurs that have aspirations of doing and handling their business hands-on in the United States, There is a common belief that O-1 is not a great option for these entrepreneurs. And I beg to differ and think that it's a great one. Traditionally, entrepreneurs that want to do their craft in the United States use visa categories such as the E-2, Trader Investor Visa, the L-1, Intra-Company Transfer Visa, and the EB-1As. if they're going for permanent residence, and EB-5 to do their craft in the United States. But all of these have limitations, and some of them just take a long time. And many of them do not support someone that wants to have a job and do their craft on the side, or if they have multiple businesses that they want to run. A lot of these solutions are tied to one business and might not even permit the foreign national to be hands-on. on the business and really rely on other workers to service that. That's not the case with the O-1. With the O-1 visa, you can be hands on your business. There is no requirement to hire anybody else to run it for you. But there are some limitations to when you are serving as a petitioner for yourself. In order for it to work as a self petitioner, that means you as your own business sponsoring yourself as a foreign national to do the O-1A, you must establish an employer employee relationship. which means that one, either you have to give up a significant amount of ownership in the business so that somebody has the authority to fire you, or you have to hire a board that has the authority to make those decisions for you. But there is a way around that that I found in my practice time as an immigration attorney and now as the managing director of Innovative Global Talent Agency. That's when you use a third party entity to serve as the petitioner. So there's someone to receive service of process that is not the individual. The way that we structure this correctly is that we serve as the petitioner for the visa. We add building the business that you want to do or the businesses as part of your itinerary. And then if you have a job, we can place that job as part of the itinerary too. With this being the case, since there's a third party involved, you no longer have the problem of accepting service of process on your own entity, and you are free as a foreign national to own 100% of your business without a board and operate several businesses at the same time, and even potentially have a full-time employment or various projects that you work on. so that's what I have to present about how the o1 can be the most flexible non-immigrant visa for entrepreneurs when structured properly with a third-party petitioner hopefully us innovative global talent agency I hope you find us helpful out there and we look forward to further educating the market on how to use o1 visas to do amazing things have a great day

And that is traveling on ESTA and visitor visas versus getting a work visa to come to the United States to play in the poker tournaments. What has happened? as we understand it, is this person has been traveling to the United States maybe four to six times per year to compete in poker tournaments where they are paid and do report those earnings on ITIN. Unfortunately, on the last trip to the United States, they were brought into secondary inspection at the port of entry and asked about their activities. and they want to know if they can continue doing these activities on ESTA, or is it best to switch to another type of visa? What I'd say is this. Important to remember that ESTA visa waivers are kind of a privileged thing and not a right. So there's not a lot of teeth that one has to combat that once they have been flagged by the CPD consular officers and border protection officers. Because while there are rules associated with ESTA, they always have the discretion to pull those away. So what we say is for poker players is that once you're flagged, the best thing to do is go ahead to switch to the P1 visa. It's something that's going to last for a while. We usually do them for three years for the first one. And there's just a lot more safety knowing that you'll get through CPV every time. And then you can also start to do other things such as accept sponsorship money, do ancillary things such as sponsorship activations, maybe even seminars here and there. to make it worth it to do that. And also, you can stay much longer in the United States and even get P4 visas for your spouse if you have one in children under the age of 21. But ultimately, the consular, the border control officers do have complete discretion when it comes to those ESTA visa waivers. So they don't really have to have a big reason to go ahead and pull those. And once you're flagged, that's kind of in the system once you've been to secondary. So in this case, I looked the person up. They were ranked as high as 170th in their country, 8,000 on the money list. And that's perfect, perfect way to go get the P1 visa. We've done visas for people that have been ranked there before. And the winnings look as high as what we've seen before and what we've done the visa. So I'd highly suggest going to the P1 visa to get that safety, knowing that you'll get through CPV. Your background looks very good as far as being eligible. And save yourself the headache. Txt Wrap: So our investment structure is simple. You are investing in people, candidates, and then participating in the return of those candidates. That's why we have two packages, and both of these reflect premium processing applications, meaning that we can get the visas done very quickly, and most of it covers government fees. So the first package is that you can sponsor two candidates for $15,000. What we do with those candidates is we'll get them the visa and then we'll present them for placement. And the reason why the return has such a big influx of what it can be on the minimum end versus the maximum end, it depends on how high the salary is that we placed them. So we like to give realistic expectations. We are not willing to place anybody in a job that's under $70,000. So at $70,000, your minimum return will be $42,000. And then even in the by chance that we did something under that, we will always give a return of at least 100% of what you put in once we do like a placement. On the higher end, if we're doing high-end individuals that have really big skill sets or even C-suite skill sets, they can be getting paid $350,000 for their job, first year salary placement. And so that's how you can get up to $210,000 just off of two candidates. The next package that we have is that you can do a 30,000 investment for five candidates. And that's just doing the math up from there so that your minimum return on a $70,000 salary is looking at 105,000. So you would come back with 60,000 of revenue. And on the high end, if we place five people at jobs of 350,000 each, then your return can get up to as much as $183,000. And who knows, maybe even more. The way the timeline works on the investment is it takes us about two months at the high end to get the visa done. And then from there, once they're placed, employers usually pay out 45 days after they felt the employee out to see if there was a match or not. In the case that somebody doesn't match and there's something not there, we can immediately put this person back into the talent pool the way we struck the visas that they're immediately available for another opportunity. You know, so it might be the case that you might get paid off multiple times after an employee. If it's the case that they do their 45 days and then maybe four months down the line, they decide that they want to change. We're still earned our fees, but that talent, that person is placed back in a talent pool with a visa that's ready to go. So that particular candidate can particularly go again. And you would again share in that revenue with them and be in business with us. So while there are these two packages, you can get as many packages as you want. So if you want to do the $30,000 package more than once, then you can just raise your candidates. For example, $90,000 will get you 15 candidates at that same rate and so forth. So I think the business model is very clear. Video Title: How the O-1 Visa can help international private wealth clients - Talent Based Migration
Video Folder Link: How the O-1 Visa can help international private wealth clients - Talent Based Migration
Recording File: How the O-1 Visa can help international private wealth clients - Talent Based Migration.mp4
Audio File: How the O-1 Visa can help international private wealth clients - Talent Based Migration.mp3
Txt Wrap: Hello, my name is Attorney Sherrod Seward, and I am an immigration attorney by trade and the managing director of Innovative Global Talent Agency. Today, I'm discussing how global citizens and private wealth clients around the world can leverage both non-immigrant and immigrant talent-based options to obtain access to the United States market, even if you don't want to live in the United States permanently. As we know, with uncertainty around the world with different conflicts and different economic stressors, there's a lot of currency value that's going up and down. So people might find themselves in a country where they're used to a certain amount of wealth, uh, meaning a certain run of things globally, but due to currency fluctuations, the value of their net worth is going down drastically. And there's a need to put the money in different types of jurisdictions that might be less, less volatile and more stable. One of those is, of course, the United States, where the dollar is very strong and very stable. A lot of clients come and ask us, well, how can we take advantage of that without necessarily having to move there on a permanent basis before we're ready? And what we do is we help facilitate these opportunities through the O-1 visa structure. Typically, when private wealth level clients want to come to the United States, they look at the EB-5 investment program. which involves at least an $800,000 investment and up to more than a million to come to the United States. And it takes a while and it's permanent residence, which means you have to stay in the United States for a certain amount of time, which usually invokes a personal income tax here in the United States. But what a lot of people in this position do not know is that you can use the 01 non-immigrant visa option, which is a visa for international people with extraordinary abilities in business, in the arts, and pretty much any industry. And you can use that to come here on a non-immigrant basis for three years, be able to open multiple businesses, multiple bank accounts, and pretty much if it's structured properly, do your business the same that you would do if you had work authorization under a green card. The thing that's different is that there's no requirement to stay in the United States for a certain amount of days per year on the O-1 visa, which means that you probably will not incur the personal income tax by staying here longer than six months if you do not want to. You can come in a couple of days a year, you can come in a couple of months a year, whatever is comfortable for you. And then if you do decide that you want to stay in the United States permanently, there's the opportunity to file for an EB-1A. which is a self-sponsored immigrant visa, comes with a green card, that is not tied to investment. It's tied to your talent-based acumen. Here at the law firm we associate with an international global talent agency, We work with lawyers that pretty much exclusively only operate in talent-based situations. So we're able to articulate arguments for individuals that are entrepreneurs, business owners, highly skilled professionals in a way that's more nuanced than attorneys that might be more general in their practice. It does come up to say, well, we need a petitioner. If you're doing the O1A, you do need a petitioner to sign off on your visa work, but when it's structured properly, they do not have to be terribly involved and your day-to-day activity if it's structured properly. And that's where Innovative Global Talent Agency comes in. We can serve as a petitioner partner for your O-1 visa and talk to you and work with you through your projects to get your itinerary together so that you will have the flexibility to do the projects that you want, open the businesses you want on the same visa, while knowing that USCIS knows you have an itinerary that will last you to three years. just by doing projects with the Innovative Global Talent Agency in a manner that's mutual beneficial for both parties. So I hope that this was informative to you. And do not forget about talent-based immigration. It could save you a lot of headaches and offer a lot of flexibility. Thank you very much.

Video Title: How Petitioner Service helps O-1 Start-up founders maintain control of business
Video Folder Link: How Petitioner Service helps O-1 Start-up founders maintain control of business

Txt Wrap: The 01A visa, and also even if you're lucky enough, the 01B visa is an excellent category for entrepreneurs doing startup, especially those that have had successful funding rounds, because a lot of those accolades can be used to get the visa. But one question that always comes up is who can serve as the petitioner and can the company of the founder itself serve as its own petitioner? The straightforward answer is no, because you cannot have full control over an entity that serves as your petitioner. There needs to be an independent entity to receive service of process. One way around that is at our innovative global talent agency, where we have a petitioner service and from our previous experience in immigration law, we know how to properly structure and use this service to not get in tied up with giving up control of your company. when you're doing a startup in the United States under the 01A or 01B. And how we do that is by using the agent functioning as the employer or the US agent for multiple employers arrangement. So how this works is Innovative Global Talent Agency will serve as the petitioner for the visa, but either structure it so that the Petitioner is an agent for multiple employers or projects that you have going on for the founder already. Or we do it as US agent navigating and directing the activities of the beneficiary founder. And the way that works is we would make some in-kind service that the founder's business would do on behalf of the talent agency and try to make that as de minimis as possible. And then also list some of the activities that the founder tends on doing, including doing for their own business while they're there. This way, the founder will be able to use a petitioner service that will stay completely, you know, pretty much out of their business, except for when it's advantageous to them. And also they would be able to pretty much do their business without having a board if they don't want to, or having to give up over 51% control in their company here to satisfy that control element when it comes to who is the petitioner. So we're going to go out, spread the word to both founders and immigration attorneys that work in the space to show them that there's another way and you can keep control with IGTA. Thank you very much.

Txt Wrap: Hello, this is attorney Sherrod Seward, and I am responding to an inquiry about whether they get an EB-1A or O-1 for a cricket professional. The person is currently in the United States under a B-1 visa with two months in, so they have four months left to go there, and they would like to be able to work, but not necessarily in cricket when they come. So the first thing that we look at is the background. When we're dealing with athletics and O1s and EV1As, a lot of time national team experience is very, very important. So here we see that they have been a captain on the U19 team, and they have played with the Pakistan international team for quite a few years. And then what we like too is that they played and coached overseas. all the way up to 2020 and still is currently doing the consultations. Now that's great because we can use both the athletic and the coaching experience in that. And it actually makes it a little bit better to say like, Hey, this is a cricket professional in this thing, rather than just an athlete, because that would make the eligibility requirement much higher. But We're looking at eligibility with this type of background. One, the national team has pretty much guaranteed that we can get an O-1 visa. And then when you add the coaching prowess, that's when we can get into a better case for the EB-1A. Now, which one is better? In this case, if they are looking to work in something other than cricket, then the EB1A is going to be more applicable because then he and his spouse can get the work authorization that's blanket. It's not put towards just one case. I mean, one type of industry. However, if they're looking to get it faster, then doing the O-1 with a petitioner service, because in this case, they do not have a petitioner to work with in the United States, would be more advantageous because you can get that done in probably two months. But with this background, we're very, very confident in the EB-1A. Now, what we would say is to do the EB-1A with premium processing so that you can get a quick decision. Now, if that decision happens to be adverse, then maybe the alternative would be to file the 01 then we should probably be at a much reduced rate because we already have all the arguments we needed for the 01 and it pretty much just be paying for the petitioner service and an hourly fee for redoing the arguments and the forms and the filing fee. So that is how we approach this situation that comes up a lot on whether they should do the ev1a or o1 first you look to see what you're eligible for here this cricket professional from their athletics and their coaching is a great candidate for both then you look to see what are you looking to do united states are you looking to work in cricket if not then the ev1a with the work authorization that comes through adjusting status is better, especially if you want the spouse to be able to work too, because we can file all those at once. And then you look at timing. If you have the time to wait for advanced parole in the United States, or if you have business that you need to wrap up in your home country, then you can do the EB-1A and look at the consular processing options as far as interview times or priority dates when it's done. But either way, this is a great candidate and we're glad to hit us up. And I hope this helped educate the people out there about O1s versus EB1As and which one makes more sense for you.

And today I'm talking about a common issue that we get from MMA and boxing managers, but particular with ones that have athletes that fight in the UFC. Typically, when international athletes fight in the UFC, they get a P1 visa. Sometimes they get P1 visas for multiple years, but a lot of times they get visas for single events. And that can be very problematic for athletes, especially ones that train in the United States and don't just come here to fight. So we had one inquiry from a fighter, a UFC fighter that lives in the United States. They have children. and a spouse in the United States, but they're currently stuck in another country because they do not have a P1 visa to come back to the United States. And they're not in a country where they have ESTA visa waivers. So pretty much they were expecting to fight in Las Vegas, which of course a P1 would be issued. But since their fight was moved to another country, they were unable to convince the promotion to get them a P1. So we're asked what can be done about that? Well, there is something that can be done, which is called a concurrent P1 or just having your own P1 anyway. You do not have to have your P1 filed by the UFC or Zufa to compete there. We have plenty, maybe even dozens of experiences where We have a third party that files for the P1 visa using the itinerary of the USC, especially if they're already signed, and getting a multi-year visa that they have and can control, which they can use to, even if they get cut, still have the visa in place if they get cut from the UFC. And they can also use that visa to get support staff persons on their own without having to wait for the UFC. So for the the managers out there that are wondering why does it make sense to obtain your own visa apart from the promoter is because you have that flexibility of knowing, one, I have a visa in place for multiple years, regardless of my contractual status. Video Title: O-1A visas for coaches - using the accomplishments of pupils and students
Video Folder Link: O-1A visas for coaches - using the accomplishments of pupils and students
Recording File: O-1A visas for coaches - using the accomplishments of pupils and students.mp4
Audio File: O-1A visas for coaches - using the accomplishments of pupils and students.mp3
Txt Wrap: Hello, my name is shared seward I'm the intake attorney here at shared sports visas innovative immigration law and right now I'm responding to a great inquiry from a tennis coach about the ability to get an oh one visa. So when we're talking about coaches, sometimes it can be challenging to get the O-1 visa because the coach is not the person themselves that's doing the accomplishments. Of course, a lot of times they're students and pupils that's doing that, which is not a problem, but it's just that we have to be careful about how we can and what's available to make those connections seamless. So not only do you have to show that your pupils did accomplish major activities, but you have to also show your contributions to it. The best way to do that is from a statement from the athlete themselves that attest that, yes, this coach had a significant contribution to my success. And the second way to do it is from independent third party verifications, whether it be from articles written about the situation that mentions both the athletes and the coach and the significance of the event. And then from there, you can also look at expert opinions that can kind of close the gap in the context of how the coach specific skills were able to help the individual. And the inquiry that we received, we saw that one of the pupils won a gold medal. That is tremendous, tremendous helpful evidence because there's something called the comparable evidence theory in 01, which specifically allows for individuals to claim that they should qualify for different eligibility criteria within 01 based on the activities of somebody they worked with. And there's a specific example that says a coach of a gold medalist is a great candidate for using the comparable evidence theory. So if you have an athlete that won a gold medal there, you can use the comparable evidence. You try to use it for single major award. A lot of times it doesn't work, but we can use that for memberships. We can use that for original contributions. We can use that, of course, for lesser awards and some of the other things that are out there. As far as like publications, publications about the student and the award, we could argue for that, too. But the thing is, we have to prove it. So if it's not something that's on the Internet readily available, where the athlete's mentioning the coach, then it's best to have a message from the athlete themselves or from people that are in the know that know them both or can ascertain to the relationship that was there of how the coach helped this person win a gold medal. And that goes for the other persons too, not necessarily the ones that won the gold medal, but any type of student that had great, great accomplishments that fit well within the O-1 theory. then the coach can also take advantage of those for the L1 visa. And in this particular case, we think this person is a great candidate based on how much they were able to help other tennis players reach the highest pinnacles of the world in sport. So we're glad to confirm this candidate and hopefully look forward to working with them. Thank you very much.

Video Title: Using O-1B and O-2 for Startup Companies - Data_ STEM & Tech
Video Folder Link: Using O-1B and O-2 for Startup Companies - Data_ STEM & Tech
Recording File: Using O-1B and O-2 for Startup Companies - Data_ STEM & Tech.mp4
Audio File: Using O-1B and O-2 for Startup Companies - Data_ STEM & Tech.mp3
Txt Wrap: Hello, this is attorney Sherrod Seward, ESQ, and I am responding in general to some inquiries I received while attending the Select USA conference in National Harbor, Maryland, where the United States Department of Trade brought in thousands of great entrepreneurs from all over the world to talk about how to invest into the United States and set up companies here. And one of the typical ways that it is pitched to do this is through the EB-5 investment program to where you have to spend at least $800,000 and usually upward of 18, $1.8 million at the end of the day to get this visa. But there's a couple of drawbacks. One is there's a lot of people invested in getting these investments. And so they push it. And then they don't talk about how long it takes to get these EB-5 visas. And then there's not a lot of attorneys out there that understand how to use the O1 structure to get better and quicker results for entrepreneurs out there that want to be back and forth between the United States and eventually immigrate here. So that's what I'm going to talk about right now. I'm talking about the O1B. version of the 01A is great for business persons that also have a outward presence, like an influencer type presence. And the big difference is because when you have an 01B person in your organization, you have the ability to file for o2 visa applications for anybody that's associated with them and it's essential support staff role so a lot of times when we meet businesses they'll have multiple founders that will all want certain types of access to the united states if they were doing eb-5 investment visas they would each have to do that investment Right. So what we like to do when possible is we'll look at the background of each of the founders or maybe even executive that has a really extensive background that might be forward facing. For example, if they've done articles, if they've appeared on news features, if they have their own content like a podcast that they put forth. And then we'll evaluate each of those founders and executives to see who are the best or the single best candidate for the one beat. We'll file the O1B visa on their behalf and then for the other founders, unless they want one for themselves, we'll do essential support staff visas. And the thing about essential support staff is we can do multiple people on the same application. So for cost efficiency, and also flexibility, that is the best structure. The 01B visa a lot of times will cost around $10,000 on the legal fee side of things, while the 02 applications are usually between $4,000 to $6,000 each. Each comes with the ability to obtain O3 visas for family members, which means spouses and children under 21 can get these O3 visas that each all last three years. And they can use that to go to school. They can't use that for work authorization, but they could definitely use that to go to school. So that's what I think is the best avenue for this.

Video Title: O-1A versus P-3 for Muay Thai Athletes to train and do seminars in the US
Video Folder Link: O-1A versus P-3 for Muay Thai Athletes to train and do seminars in the US
Recording File: O-1A versus P-3 for Muay Thai Athletes to train and do seminars in the US.mp4
Audio File: O-1A versus P-3 for Muay Thai Athletes to train and do seminars in the US.mp3
Txt Wrap: Hello, this is immigration attorney and talent manager Sherrod Seward responding to a great question about Muay Thai athletes and what category is best for them to come to the United States. Of course, it depends on why. In this particular case, we understand that the Muay Thai athletes are coming to coach and do seminars as opposed to just compete in competitions. For that reason, the P1 visa is out And we're now looking at the O-1 visa, which is for extraordinary ability for nationals. And we're looking at the P-3 visa, which is for cultural significance. And the question is, which one's the best? The best one to get is the O1 if they qualify. If they're high enough achievement that they've done great things that would put them in the top of their field when they were competing, or even as coaches now that when they're done competing and have continued to contribute to their sport, we would do the O1. The O1 gets three years. That's why it's really good. And it also has a great breadth of flexibility when it comes to work authorization. So you can do seminars. You can do coaching. You could even compete if you want to. There's a lot you can do with that. The thing with the O1 is just more expensive. To do an O1 application, you're usually looking around $10,000 in legal fees on top of the filing fees that are there for each athlete. Now, sometimes you can do an O1 visa for one of the athletes, and if they have rapport together, you can get the other athletes there as essential support staff. which are usually around 2,000 per individual. And you can put multiple individuals on a single essential support staff application. So if the best one of them gets an O-1, then the rest, if they try to train together or have some rapport together, you can put the rest of them on an O-2 visa application based on that O-1. And there would only be really two filing fees that you're doing, one for the O-1 and one for the O-2s. The second way to do it is say, for example, if there's a budget constraint or if there is no one of those athletes that have the background to get the O1 themselves, then of course you can look at the P3 in this circumstance. The P3 is appropriate when there is a cultural tie to that particular nation of the activity taking place. In this case, Muay Thai originates from Thailand, where they're from, and is the national sport of the country. Not only does it have the sport kind of acumen, but it's also very intrinsically bound into the fabric of how the spirit of the country works. People from all over the world come to Thailand to learn Muay Thai skills because that's where it was born and that's where the best training can happen. So definitely there is a pathway for the P3 to be used in this circumstance. Now we'll talk on the practical side of it. So the P3, unfortunately, is only available for a year at a time. And it still takes pretty significant documentation to do these visas. So even though the P3 is only good for a year, it really takes about the same amount of work as an O1 in many cases to get it through. For that case, there's a lot of time it prices out of what people are willing to pay on the legal fees for doing a P3. So what we do is sometimes at the talent agency, we'll take on a consulting role in bringing in athletes and helping them find opportunities. So if it was something where you're looking at the P3, it probably wouldn't be with the law firm. It would probably be something that would need to be sponsored on an individual basis. by the talent agency, which has its own fee, which is much less, and the talent agency would apply on its own for those particular visas. Now, the thing about the P3 is that you can apply for multiple persons on the same filing. So if you have individuals that have rapport with each other, they can be brought on a single P3 application for multiple beneficiaries, which further helps with the cost of doing this. um so that's best how to answer your question if there is one with the background and the resources are there uh the o1 is the longer option and the most robust if there is a budget concern and there's a background a concern where not any of the athletes would be um eligible for their own O-1 visa, then the P-3 on a consulting basis might be the most applicable option. So I hope this was helpful to everybody out there, and especially the person that asked this question. And we look forward to doing more Muay Thai.

In this case, we have someone that is very adamant about getting an EB1A, and we did a consultation for them, and we're going to share this video with them as well. That speaks to why, in their case, it may be more advantageous to go for the EB2 with a national interest waiver, an NIW. That's because it's a less, depending on your industry and the times and circumstances of what is filed the national interest waiver can have a much less burden bar to be eligible than the eb-1a there's no way of getting around on the eb-1a that you have to be one of the best in the world at your field and we have different ways of articulating that to our favor but it is always a hard hill to climb but we do it all the time the thing is sometimes you don't have to In the ideal world, we would file for both the EB-1A and the EB-2 national interest waiver if the client has the resources to do it. That's just because it gives you more chance to get a fair adjudication from the officers because you'll likely have two different officers because they're two different preference categories. Now, this particular person is a STEM and data computer tech, and they have good citations. They have contributions to projects that have significance. And the subject area of what they're doing, these activities are considered right now very important. To be specific, right now, the Biden administration has a huge push on keeping the best minds in STEM and artificial intelligence in the country. So while they are here in office, which is at least until January, it's a great time to take advantage of the NIW because you can put forth the administration's own words as powerful, persuasive arguments to why the national interest waiver applies. Now, what does the national interest waiver do? Well, to back up, if you're doing an EB-2 without one, you're going to need a job offer in order to pursue the EB-2 and probably get a labor certification. With the NIW, what it is saying is that this person's skill and their skillset background and what they can contribute to the United States in the future is so prevalently important that we should weigh the requirement of every job offer, which means that we also do not have to do a labor certification. It's potentially the same thing as an EB-1, EB-1A, but instead of approving your own acumen as one of the best in the world in your field, you're just saying that what you happen to do is worthy of being let in the United States with a green card, regardless of a job offer or not, and with no labor certification, which in this case, we have a lot of information out there directly from the administration that adjudicates these petitions that what you do is very important. And that's the reason why we consider the EB-2 National Interest Waiver to be the best option in this circumstance, besides applying for both at the same time. The problem comes in is when the NFL team or players association might not get the concept and they say, yes, we want a consultation letter that's petitioned for by this entity or the team. Then that's going to create problems that are much worse than if they just said nothing and just let us make our requests and ignore this. It's much worse. The other thing that comes in with USCIS having bogus adjudications is they look at the contract of the player and say like, well, it looks like they're saying they have to play for this team, which counteracts their decision of just choosing where they play, which of course is, I don't know, just pretty asinine because obviously the player gets to choose which team that he's getting ready to play for. A player can then opt to not play for that team or sit out a year. There's a lot of ways to say how they will navigate where they go. But the USS decision on one of our cases was pretty much like, no, it's the team that navigates and directs where they will play, not the player that ultimately decides what team they will play on. So for that reason, we are most often advocating that players get an O-1 visa just because there's a lot more leeway to play with the schedule and itinerary of what you will be doing rather than a P-1, because if you are on a P-1 then you will be required to show that you have competitions in mind that will require the participation of internationally recognized athletes. Second is you're more privy and prone to being boxed in by the NFL Players Association if we get into an issue about the consultation letter. That's only happened once where it's been a problem. Most of the time we're able to get around it, but it did come up once and it's got our attention. The next thing is, When you're an O visa, you're in a category that's much better than the P1 because you can do other things just rather than just compete. The problem comes in sometimes if you come to teams that are unfamiliar with exotic structures for doing the visa, they'll push back and want to change the visa from an O1 to a P1, which is one, a much less prestigious visa to be on with more restrictions. And then second is if they cut that player Now we have to extra work to do to put them back in that other status. So if they just let the 01 rock, there would be no problem with signing them on that O visa and going about this business. And if something happens where the relationships cut short, then there would be no problem. Just letting the player go and he still has his visa intact to do other things. But if they go and file a P1 that changes the status from 01 to P1 or changes his own P1 to the team's P1, when that's reduced, now the player has to either leave the country to come back. on his previous approval or we have to file another petition to reinstate that previous status so it's one of those things that could be avoided with more education and talking to the teams about transparency and how this works which is something that we'll continue to do to give more opportunities to four foreign national football players to enjoy the same opportunities and speed and access to teams as foreign-born players And I think we could all say that we're enjoying the diversity that's in football, getting a lot of different flavors, a lot of different type of athletes. And the teams are appreciating those extra set of skill sets that they're getting as well to compete for the Super Bowl. And with that being said, I hope to continue doing updates on the work we're doing in football and talk to you soon. Peace.

Video Title: Sherrod Seward_ Esq_ speaks on visa issues for minor league athletes

I thought it important to speak on this topic because it's coming up a lot in two major sports here in the United States where a lot of people come to compete at the minor league level. And that is soccer, football. I'm talking as is like the regular football and cricket. And these are both sports where there's a lot of minor league participation. And when I mean minor league, I'm not talking about the league that's right under MLS or U.S. Major Cricket. I think it's called the Major Cricket League or something like that. Major League Cricket. We're talking about third tier and fourth tier leagues where we're starting to get a lot of calls because there's a lot of issues and confusions about the ability of players to get visas to compete in these leagues. Now, the first question is, can you compete in these leagues on visitor visas? And the answer is yes, if you're not getting paid or if you're only getting paid prize money. But if you're getting paid anything that is anything other than that, like a stipend or a salary or even in-kind payment, then you're still going to have issues with work authorization if you're competing for this type of money that's not prize money in these minor league leagues. The other problem that we have is the eligibility of the individuals to obtain P-one visas and just the eligibility criteria. Let's deal with that first. A lot of times the talent that is coming to compete in these leagues, it's hard for them to satisfy the criteria of getting a P-one visa on their own. If you don't know, P-one visas are for internationally recognized athletes and there's certain categories that you have to feel to satisfy that if you're doing it as an individual. And that is like an international ranking, which you usually don't have if you're in a team sport or if you have individual awards that are awarded to you. But a lot of times team sports don't have, as opposed if you were a swimmer, which has a very robust international ranking system that's universally accepted or boxing, something like that matter. But in team sports, you tend not to have those type of accolades that make you applicable for a P-one visa on your own. But there is two ways that you can get P-one visas as a team. One is like as a team, you competed with some other people before and collectively you have international rankings, awards that make you satisfactory to the eligibility requirement of P-ones. The other is the Compete Act. And that is usually the best, most consistent way that athletes competing in minor leagues can get P-one visas. The Compete Act is applicable to leagues that have at least six teams and a collective revenue of over ten million dollars. While that might not seem like a lot, a lot of these sports leagues that are operating are not generating that type of money yet till they get to a certain threshold. And the problem that happens is if Well, here's a good thing. If you're under the Compete Act, you do not have to get the individual eligibility for each P-I visa. It's kind of assumed that the people that are competing have the eligibility portion of their visa satisfied. And it's great because this is where historically it comes from. Historically, minor league hockey teams used to use up all the H-B visas trying to get players during the winter months. And those H-B visas are typically held to the side for agricultural workers. are workers that work in seasonal amusement parks and stuff like that so to stop beating up on the quota of those h-to-bs during hockey season that's when they came up with the compete act so that hockey players could come on p-one visas even if they didn't have those eligibility requirements typical of international recognized athletes at a p-one level and leave the h-to-b cap on uh unmasked with So when I get players interested, both in cricket, football, and even basketball, interested in a visa, and they say they're playing with a minor league I've never heard before, it's always like, let me talk to the league first, see what type of revenue they have, because if they don't have the Compete Act, criteria met is going to be a very hard battle and probably you'll have to end up on a visitor visa and playing for free and not getting paid under the table that's bad all right so I hope that clears that up about how minor leagues the compete act and p-one visas all interact with each other to give either your great chance of coming here on a work visa to play with a minor league team or if it's just you're gonna have to wait and get your credentials up and become eligible for a individual P-one visa without the Compete Act. Hope you find that helpful and I'm going to try to do this more often. Thank you very much.
